awd_titl_txt: Academic and Social STEM Excellence for Transfer Students (ASSETS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Department of Technology and Society in the Stony Brook University (SBU) College of Engineering and Applied Sciences will establish an S-STEM project, titled "Academic and Social STEM Excellence for Transfer Students". The project will provide scholarship support for students who have completed an Associate's degree and who enroll in a STEM major at SBU. The project will incorporate a two week mathematics immersion program and will also make available a network of advising, career, and academic support structures. Data will be collected to identify specific academic transition issues and the use of base-line data will allow us to determine the effectiveness of the interventions that have been designed for this proposal.  

The project integrates scholarship support, subject-specific academic support, engagement in research and career preparation (through faculty mentoring and internships), as well as program assessment and assessment of the impact of the program on students' academic performance, persistence in S-STEM disciplines, and attitudes. The results of the project will add to the literature of helping community college student achieve successful transitions to four year institutions. The proposed S-STEM project will be a model for addressing the Nation's  needs for producing more STEM educated students and further enhance the economic competitiveness of the United States and the Metropolitan New York Regions. The model illustrates an effective way of engaging students in STEM disciplines and careers and could be adapted to other institutional contexts so as to expand access to and excellence in STEM disciplines.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The ASSETS program supports economically disadvantaged, academically talented STEM CC students transferring to STEM majors at Stony Brook University. The ASSETS scholarship covers most (if not all) of scholar’s tuition and the program features a 2-week math bootcamp, research and career preparation, and numerous team building and student support activities. Since 2017, ASSETS has awarded about $550,000 in scholarships to 66 award recipients (average yearly amount $5,600 amount) in 15 STEM departments.

Over the past 4 years of the project, the management team has learned many interesting lessons to improve transfer student success. First, face-to-face instruction is important to build strong cohorts, but it is possible to mix virtual and face to face interactions to make the program more sustainable and widely available to non-traditional students. We also learned that students who do not participate in early team building exercises are more likely to stay isolated throughout their college experience. ASSETS gets students involved before classes begin to minimize student isolation. Finally, a major benefit of the program was that students interacted with faculty, staff, and university leadership, such as deans and provosts. This immediately transferred into students being more willing to approach faculty when they had difficulty in class, needed recommendation letters, or wanted to conduct research.

Intellectual Merit: ASSETS has increased our knowledge of the impact of scholarships on transfer students. One of original research questions was that the scholarship would decrease the need for students to work part time jobs. We discovered that students who had jobs before the scholarship kept working, but the scholarship decreased the number of hours they worked and their financial stress. The support programs, like the bootcamp and career mentoring, gave students more confidence to speak with faculty and pursue research opportunities. For publications see works cited30

Broader impacts: ASSETS serves as a model to produce more STEM students that enhances the economic competitiveness of Long Island, and New York regions. ASSETS helps community college students succeed when transferring to SBU. The program targets low-income students, women, and students from underrepresented minority groups. ASSETS trained 3 women graduate researchers over the 5 years and two of them remain in higher education administration working to diversify STEM fields.

 


Last Modified: 06/13/2023
Modified by: Thomas Woodson
